His voice is strained and lacking and over-dramatically deliberate, just like it's always been.  His lyrics, as always, sound like a Hippa-Christian on a Soho street corner in 1968(Love will take us to the mountain, lalalala, jump! Jump with me! Jump, Ju-no, no, just spiritually....kerplunk-oops)<br /><br />But when the Edge is on and his frenetic and brilliant etchings that somehow evoke desolation and awe and wonder all in the same moment permeate a U2 song, then you see who brought this band from I Will Follow all the way to Vertigo.  It makes the pompous and grotesque commercialism of them and IPODs just funny.  Yet, with a wink, Bono seems to know his place in the band-knows that his supporting members and himself, have a certain magic that won't be remembered in the middle of the road ballads that don't hold up on a Best of album, or the ridiculous attempts at hip-hop and electronica  in the lost 90's decade, but instead, long after the wind has died and the birds are quiet over the ruins of the rock and roll landscape, there on the Edge will be this manic, lilting guitar carrying us all to a higher place.

0446677450|4.0|In summary, this book teaches three concepts: <br /> <br />1.  The relationship between (net) income and assets <br />2.  Shedding the old dogmas/the need for financial literacy <br />3.  Taking risks and learning from them <br /> <br />RDPD is dead on the mark when it comes to the concept of building up your assets and letting them do the work for you.  The primary means of doing this are: <br /> <br />1.  Spending less than you make  <br />2.  Saving/investing your profits.   <br /> <br />He calls this 'the relationship between income and assets'.    <br /> <br />No matter how simple this shounds, this philosophy is largely forgotten in today's 'spend now/pay later' society.  If Americans could heed this advice alone, their financial lives would be much better off.  This concept is made elegantly in RDPD. <br /> <br />RDPD doesn't stop there.  It continues on to essentially say that in order to be really really rich, you need to look at the world with a new set eyes and use your brain (called 'financial literacy').  Financial literacy is the ability to shed the old dogmas of working hard/studying hard to get a decent paying job and look at the world with an eye to identifying opportunities. <br /> <br />The author chose real estate and (I think) private placement stock offerings.  By no means are these the only ways to make grow your income earning assets, but the author doesn't really elaborate on other areas.  I get the sad (but probably incorrect) impression that his real estate wealth came from those late night, get rich commericals/seminar programs.  This is one aspect of the book that I can't shake. <br /> <br />RDPD tells you that simply investing in the stock market in mutual funds is 'fine' and that owning your own home is actually a drain on your cash flow/net worth.  These didn't come as a terrible shock to me, but to those who thought they were on the right track, (spending less than they make, diligently saving/investing) they might be a bit turned off by these revelations. <br /> <br />However, making money is about taking risks.  Investing in mutual funds and owning a home are generally low risk/long term strategies.  To really make money by growing your assets, one needs to use their brain and take risks, which is the third message of the book.  Although I believe the author glosses over the risks, they are there, specifically his losses on the stock investments.   <br /> <br />Another thing to keep in mind is that making money still takes time.  It can't be done in one day.  Even the author notes that he had to consistently trade up properties and has had to make many stock investments (and suffered many losses) to get to where he is today (before he started selling books).  But these losses and property trade ups were treated as lessons learned to constanly fine tune his 'financial literacy', a very key part of his strategy.  <br /> <br />All in all, if Americans could learn and adhere to the first lesson of the book, they'd be much be off.  Step 3 IMO can come after people shore up their personal finances (essentially step 1).

B0006399FS|4.0|Achtung readers: I am not a music critic, I just pretend to be one for free. <br /> <br />Let me begin by saying this album was hugely promoted across the world, boasted expectations of its brilliance, and left us wondering what U2 possibly could have up their sleeves.  The time has come to face this beast and see what is made of, or should I say, what we are made of.  On the day of its release, we are left to ponder the result that is HTDAAB.  Rather, I am left to ascertain whether it truly is everything it said it would be, and much more (it is U2, so I expect this of them). I had certain ideas of what this album of songs should sound like, therefore, what it would sound like.  I think I expected something other-worldly with this record.  Not exactly Achtung Baby, but something totally new, never before seen in the history of rock and roll, that commented on the current state of the world.  And let me just say this record is nothing like this idea of mind-bending music that I had thought existed. Upon first listen, I was like \\"what?\\".  It blindsided the left side of my brain, especially my pre-conceived notions of U2 rock.  It had tried to listen to the Bomb in a linear manner, and then draw conclusions after that first listen.  Big mistake.  It may be a slightly over-produced (one of my few critiques of the album), but it is in no way safe or logical.  In no way is it an overtly political album, but it does make loud statements about the current state of one's heart, soul, and mind.  It is essentially not a literal white-flag U2 Album, but rather the white flag that should exist within one's own state of being (thus the way we are, the way we reflect upon the world and act within it).  The Joshua Tree spoke to my heart, Achtung Baby to my ego and mind, and HTDAAB speaks directly to my soul.  I know, some people reading this right now are laughing.  But I truly believe this.  When I feel something, I really feel it.  On the surface, HTDAAB seems like straightforward rock, but after a couple of listens, I knew I had something great beneath the polish of production. <br /> <br />I am not going to give this album a track by track review, because all listeners have favorites and least favorites.  There are strong tracks and less strong tracks.  There are some of the best lyrics Bono has ever penned, but also some of the cheesiest.  The guitars and rhythm section have never sounded better, but also not overly new sounding.  New sounds do not necessarily equal great stuff, however.  I am currently not skipping any song on this disc, which is unlike in the past when I have been known from time to time to skip some U2 tracks. <br /> <br />One track in particular, though, sums up my feeling for this album and where U2 are at this point in their careers, One Step Closer.  Closer to what, and how far away are they?  Only time will tell.  But, in all truth, U2 are being honest with their state of mind (does honesty = a release?) and where they are amongst the trash and glitter of the world.  They are fessing up to themselves in this complexly simple album.  They are an epic band making victorious music, but still are searching. <br /> <br />\\"Simplicity is indeed often the sign of truth and a criterion of beauty.\\" - Mahlon Hoagland (Toward the Habit of Truth) <br /> <br />9/10 or 4.25 stars  <br /> <br />

B00068IOWC|5.0|With \\"How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb\\" it can be said that U2 have finally come full circle. After a decade of experimenting, touring and putting their stamp on practically every popular genre of music from techno to classical, the band returns to the basics of what made their sound so fresh and their songs such popular classics. The usual U2 messages, ideas and questions are here, but with an urgency and style that is truly visceral and highly emotional. U2 is the biggest band in the world precisely because their music is full of so much passion and heart. Their songs are perfectly adaptable to radio, but they don't sound particularly made for simple commercial value. Like The Beatles, U2 knows how to churn out a hit but with great technical, melodic and emotional qualities. The opening number, \\"Vertigo,\\" is classic rock n' roll with a spacey, almost futuristic punkish feel that calls you back for another listen. The Edge really brings down the house here with his exhilarating guitar playing while Bono's lyrics are cryptive and fun. The ballad \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own\\" keeps the tradition of long song titles from the band but it has a power and punch that few ballads these days could ever hope to achieve. Decorated with beautiful slide guitar and an almost operatic section, this song has a timeless quality. \\"Love And Peace Or Else\\" is a dark, dramatic turn for the album. Is it a statement on the Iraq war? Or on the state of the world in general? Who knows, but the band makes it roar like a soaring anthem with heavy guitar licks in an almost Iggy Pop tradition. \\"How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb\\" is a masterful album because like so many few albums, it is completely filled with great songs. Even the weaker tracks sound skillfull, like \\"One Step Closer.\\" \\"City Of Blinding Lights\\" is another strong track with a dreamy feeling and slick production. The return of original U2 producer Steve Lillywhite is most welcome here, especially on a hard rocking tracklike \\"All Because Of You\\" which is driving and exhilarating. \\"Crumbs From Your Table\\" is a wonderful love song, full of heartbreak and tender guitar melodies. Even now that U2 has dropped the excessive techno romping of \\"Pop,\\" they still go over the top, which is where we like them. Like the best rock albums, glorious excess is where this band shines best as in their previous masterpieces like \\"Achtung Baby\\" and even to some degree \\"Rattle And Hum.\\" \\"How To Dismantle An Atomic Bomb\\" is more of \\"The Joshua Tree\\" but for the 21st century. Bono's words are rich and full of spiritual flourishes while the Edge, drummer Larry Mullen Jr. and bassist Adam Clayton provide a smooth, sometimes heavy backdrop that sounds like pure, untarnished rock n' roll. This isn't just an album for U2 fans, rockers or 80's nostalgics (because this band has not stayed in the 80's), this is an album for ANYONE looking for majestic, exhilarating music.
B0002IU988|5.0|I loved Creed and bought all of their CDs and I understand there were many who completely hated them. But, you should give this a chance. Seems to be about the new band, and realizing their different than Creed. <br />COM-9 <br /> <br />4. Burn It Down-9-Bluesy feel to it, very groovy, about starting over after you've messed up. Another awesome solo and good bass. <br />COM-6 <br /> <br />5-Metalingus-9-Very fast-paced and hard-hitting. Excellent song combining \\"cunnlingus\\" and \\"metal\\" to make \\"Metalingus\\" which I believe means stimulation of the metal-head that is in everyone, some just more than others. No solo, still good ax work. Awesome drums. No Creed here. About regretting the past and having an ephiphany. <br />COM-1 <br /> <br />6-Broken Wings-10-Maybe the best song on here. Very passionate. About standing up up for waht you believe in sacrificing yourself for it (possibly Biblical) or someone (as in war). <br />COM-7 <br /> <br />7-In Loving Memory-10-For those of you that don't know, Tremonti lost his mother recently to a brain tumor and now he's written a tear-jerking song in tribute to her. It is honest and touching. Very good. <br />COM-9 <br /> <br />8-Down to My Last-9-Excellent song that seems to have many meanings. The first verse seems to be a tribute to rock legends, the second verse seems to be a statement to Creed haters, and the pre-choruses (I think that's what they're called) seem to be to his mother. Nice solo. <br />COM-7 <br /> <br />9-Watch Your Words-8-Slaps you in the face out of some more Creed-like tunes. No solo, just heavy guitar playing, good song. Obviously, about regretting something you said, seems to have some religious lyrics as well. <br />COM-2 <br /> <br />10-Shed My Skin-10-Awesome song personal to Tremonti about maturing and talking about his past. Excellent ending. <br />COM-8 <br /> <br />11-The End Is Here-7-Weakest song for me, still pretty solid. Nice ending. Again, kinda about standing up for what you believe until the day you die. <br />COM-2 <br /> <br />There you have it. Recommended. Give it a chance, you Creed-hater. <br /> <br />Overall Rating: 101/110-92% kick-ass <br />Creed-O-Meter: 56/110-50% Creed free
006092988X|5.0|It is the first book that I read that really made an impression on me, and I was only 13 years old the first time I read it (That was over 40 years ago!).  I did not even realize how strong an impression it made until years later, as I began to grow and mature as a person.  I recently (1 year ago) sought out and bought a new copy for my two teenage daughters to read.  <br /> <br />I identified with Francie's plight, growing up in a 'poor', but rural, area, and becoming 'aware of life' at 13, when I first read the book.   <br /> <br />Betty Smith's portrayal of a 'survivor' of a disfunctional life and time is 'universal' and timeless.  Her poignant reflections of a young girl struggling and learning 'against the odds' are heartfelt and enduring. <br /> <br />(I believe she was a strong influence in my love of writing and story-telling)

B00068IOWM|4.0|Overall, the Collector's Edition is a MUST for any serious U2 fan. <br /> <br />THE CD: <br />I was expecting nothing more than an additional chapter of U2-Mach 3, which began with their most literal (and least poetic) record, `All That You Can't Leave Behind' (2000).  Of course, the profile of that record, and in particular, the uplifting singles \\"Stuck in a Moment\\" and \\"Walk On\\", straddling the fence between the realm of classic U2 and the stereotype knee-jerk anthems, were undoubtedly boosted by 9/11. <br />In a sense, my expectations were met - this record is also pretty literal.  But it is also much more personal.  Like the 2002 single, \\"Electrical Storm\\", the predominant them is love in a world of chaos.  Here is a song-by-song review: <br /> <br />1. \\"Vertigo\\".  With the state of radio being what it is (and not what it was in the age of `The Joshua Tree'), why not release a new song as a commercial for one of the biggest (and most importantly, still hip) innovations in the music industry - the IPod?  The brilliant marketing worked - the more I hear it, the more this tune grows on me, despite being nothing more than \\"Elevation II.\\" <br /> <br />2. \\"Miracle Drug\\".  The idea here is big anthems and big themes.  Although this song builds like \\"Beautiful Day\\" and has some of the Edge's best slide guitar work, the song's potential as a single is undermined by the obtuseness of the lyrical simile (\\"I've had enough of romantic love/I'd give it all up for a miracle drug\\"). <br /> <br />3. \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own\\".  If \\"Miracle Drug\\" is the musical counterpart of \\"Beautiful Day\\", then this is the counterpart of \\"Stuck in a Moment\\" (complete with a nice falsetto performance by the Edge).  That said, this tune, years in the making while Bono's father was suffering from cancer that eventually took his life in August 2001, is arguably the best moment on the record (\\"I don't need to hear you say/That if we weren't so alive/You'd like me a whole lot more.\\")<br /> <br />4. \\"Love and Peace or Else\\".  In the pre-release press, much was made of the producer shuffle on this record, as U2 ultimately tagged Steve Lillywhite, the original producer of their first three records (1980-1983).  However, the award-winning team of Brian Eno and Daniel Lanois take the helm for the most original track on the record - a bluesly barroom boogie buried in an ominous soundscape and perhaps the only overtly political tune on the record - showing that the band has not completely abandoned their desire to stretch musically, which was more a characteristic of U2 in the 1990s. <br /> <br />5. \\"City of Blinding Lights\\".   I was glad to hear Flood take the production helm (does anyone remember the grossly underrated `Pop' (1997)), but unfortunately, this mid-tempo ode to Bono's wife and musical hat-tipper to The Cure is really not one of the stronger tracks. <br /> <br />6. \\"All Because of You\\".  Bono initially characterized this as a rock record, with the Edge re-discovering the guitar and the band resisting their post-punk anti-rock inclinations.  In actuality, the acoustic guitar is very prominent on this record.  However, only \\"Vertigo\\" and \\"All Because of You\\" are true rock songs in the traditional sense.  Although this tune will likely be a pick for a second or third single, the band should have left such thinly-veiled, knee-jerk religious sentiments (\\"All because of you/I am\\") to the disastrous second record, `October' (1981). <br /> <br />7. \\"A Man and a Woman\\".  This is another love song, the sound of which screams \\"adult contemporary\\".  That said, I immediately liked it.  Bono provides some of his best vocals/lyrics (\\"I could never take a chance/At losing love for romance\\"), the Edge delivers a subtle acoustic guitar, and Adam Clayton drives a nice bass line for a really strong tune that did not receive much hype prior to the release of the record. <br /> <br />8. \\"Crumbs from Your Table\\".  Obstensibly, this is another love song (\\"Fromthe brightest star/Comes the blackest hole/You had so much to offer/Why did you offer your soul/I was there for you, baby/When you offered your hand/Why did you offer your soul/Would you deny to others/What you demand for yourself/Cool down, mama!/Cool it off!\\").  But as with many other great U2 songs, the song takes on another life and eventually comes to sound like a love letter from Bono and the rest of the world to the post-9/11 United States (\\"Where you live should not decide/Whether you live or whether you die\\"). <br /> <br />9. \\"One Step Closer\\".  As a return to the ethereal sounds of `The Unforgettable Fire' (1984), Bono's choice of lower octave for the vocals gives the song promise.  But ultimately, it feels more like an incomplete poem. <br /> <br />10. \\"Original of the Species\\".  Although the first ten seconds (a haunting and simple piano line) are promising, the song ultimately devolves into a rather forgettable, over-orchestrated tune much in the vein of \\"City of Blinding Lights\\". <br /> <br />11. \\"Yahweh\\".  No subtlety here.  See \\"All Because of You\\" and `October' record. <br /> <br />12. \\"Fast Cars.\\"  If you purchase the collector's edition box set or the import version of the record, you will find the bonus track, \\"Fast Cars\\", which was left off the album proper not because of quality, but because of its not-like-the-others sound.  That said, this middle-eastern influenced acoustic romp, pontificating upon the emptiness of modern existence (\\"Don't you worry about your mind/You should worry the day your pain goes away\\"), is quite a refreshing change for U2. <br /> <br />THE DVD: <br />The DVD is a very nice addition, featuring: <br /> <br />1. \\"U2 + 3\\".  This is a well-made 20-minute in-studio documentary on the making of the record, and in particular, the tunes \\"Sometime You Can't Make It On Your Own\\", \\"Crumbs from Your Table\\", and \\"Vertigo\\". <br /> <br />2. \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own\\" (performance video) <br /> <br />3. \\"Crumbs from Your Table\\" (live studio performance) <br /> <br />4. \\"Vertigo\\" (Temple Bar Mix).  (I loved this - Bono accompanied only by the Edge on banjo!) <br /> <br />5. \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own\\" (Bono/Edge acoustic couch mix) <br /> <br />6. \\"Vertigo\\" (performance video - NOT the official video) <br /> <br />THE BOOK: <br />For the collector's edition, U2 have taken a page (so to speak) from Pearl Jam and Radiohead, bands that have long since included band artwork and various musings (i.e., not lyrics) intimating the meaning of the songs, with the inclusion of a hard-cover book.
0385512104|2.0|I finally decided to purchase this book after all the great reviews i read.  Sadly, I was left disappointed after reading the final page.  This was not a great book, at best it was an interesting story with a few gems of knowledge.  Overall, I give this book 2 Amazon Stars.

B0006399FS|5.0|This album rocks. I know that's a cliched statement, but it's true. Being a fan of U2 in the 80's but growing a little tired of the overexposure, I was thrilled when Achtung Baby came out. Since then, my appreciation for U2 has only grown. I've loved all their albums since, even the under-appreciated Pop. But this is an album for both diehards and newcomers.  <br /> <br />A few reviews have said Bono & co. are repeating past glories. My question is, so what? They're putting a new spin on some classic U2 sounds. They've never had an album that's sounded louder and more aggressive. Yet, it's not simply volume without soul. Some of the most moving elements about the album are the heart-felt lyrics and the passionate way Bono renders them.   <br /> <br />Do you like U2? Buy this album. Are you tired of U2? Buy this album. It's worth it. So much music today is uninspired. This shows a group doing what they've done for two decades--put soul back into rock and roll.

B0002TT0NW|3.0|1) A lack of continuity with the Novel.  2) Key character motivations have changed; Draco Malfoy is reduced to nothing more than a caricature - a far cry from the pureblood prince convinced of his inherent superiority; Dumbledore provides uncomfortable and uncharacteristic comic relief at critical junctures in the film.  3)Characters have been inserted that did not originate with the book at the director's discretion.  4) The Mexican references and visual symbology, while undoubtably a tribute to the director's heritage, are a distraction since the novels are decidedly British in undertone.  5)The Prisoner of Azkaban (novel) is transitional, marking the end of youth and a passage into darker times to come; yet the director, inexplicably, after having made every effort to distinguish this film from its predecessors as darker and more mature, decides to terminate the movie on a childishly triumphant note with Harry soaring over Hogwarts on his new Firebolt.  An epilogue with Wormtail roaming the forests of Albania in search of Voldemort's lingering shadow, thereby fufilling Professor Trelawney's prophecy, would have served nicely as an ending.  6) In the film, Wormtail is a bloated toad; in the novels, he is a wasted, thin, paranoid wreck of a wizard.  7) For all its length, the film seems \\"rushed\\".  8) Machines do not function at Hogwarts because of all the magical interference; yet Professor Lupin is able to play a phonograph with no difficulty.  9) Ginny Weasley does not appear in the film at all.  10) Ghostly knights on horseback barrel through the castle repeatedly; while the Bloody Baron, Headless Nick, and Peeves are nowhere to be seen.
B0002KVULG|4.0|I love this movie.  <br /> <br />That's really all that needs said on the topic but given our culture's obsession with explanations, I will proceed with further comments. Firstly it's a very romantic, soft approach to a story that has otherwise been brutalized in the cinema. Most Dracula films drench the audience in blood and give us gruesome depictions of leering fangs, while this one alludes to things but is never expressly gory or gruesome. It's a softer approach that appeals in particular to females. Of course, who could doubt that -- one glimpse of Frank Langella sweeping into Lucy's life and carelessly tossing his long, menacing black cloak to the nearest forgotten servant is enough to set any woman's head spinning. Forget the composure of most villains, Dracula has all the beguiling sexuality of a dozen infamous Don Juans that send the very Victorian women in his life to utter confusion. Frank Langella was ingenious for the part, reprising a role he'd already defined on Broadway. <br /> <br />Everyone complains about the quality transfer and how this film has been forced into a nearly black and white canvas in order to create a gothic effect. Having not seen the original, I didn't find it disappointing, just a fabulous mood-setter. I know this will probably regulate my review to the bottom of the pile, but it's a matter of preference that lends a certain morbid flair to the piece. They had a marvelous palate to work with in the first place, from the Grecian architecture of the castle to the morose English countryside in midwinter, when death surrounds the morbid asylum and its pensive graveyard. The film manages to be very haunting and beautiful at the same time, indwelling romance while never allowing us to forget the sinister surroundings. <br /> <br />For concerned parents and sensitive viewers, the R-rating seems heavy handed in comparison to most modern films. Gore is minimal, language is nonexistent, and sexual content consists more of underlining tension and passionate kissing than anything heavy-handed. The extras are also very nice, although in some respects the director's commentary rehashes much of what we've already heard on the featurette, which is by far the most marvelous addition. Interviews with some of the cast and crew, as well as reminiscences about filming, remind us that this wasn't just a movie, it was an adventure from beginning to end, from Laurence Olivier's increasingly bad health but persistent determination to do his best (and he turns in a fine performance) to Frank Langella's surprising thoughts on the film's love scene. <br /> <br />It may not please anyone desiring leering fangs and blood spattered walls, but I certainly enjoyed it.

B0006399FS|3.0|Yup, it's another mixed review album - and honestly, I feel the same way. <br /> <br />Many reviewers, and undoubtedly many listeners, have heard this album and declared it is `boring,' `thin,' etc.  Even many U2 fans have spoken these words!  In essence, some of them are correct.  Looking deep into many of the songs you may be able to find deep meanings and `inspiring ballads,' but the truth is this is a rock band producing a rock album and rock fans expect instant entertainment.  On these fronts Vertigo and All Because of You will deliver.  For the rest, people will remain in limbo.  I would enjoy many of these slower songs if they sounded like `Where the Streets Have No Name' or `With or Without You,' but they don't come across as classics. <br /> <br />We should all remember to not speak to soon, though, as many listeners are aware that U2's songs do grow on you.  But I can say that I can best review an album from the world's perspective from the first few listens (a paradigm I currently occupy), and I'm giving it a grade C+.  Being a U2 fan, I am patient in listening to the songs in their entirety and looking close at lyrics, etc.  But while sharing a perspective of another reviewer here I'm forced to agree that I get a certain distraction while listening.  I seem to start thinking about work or wondering about tomorrow's weather forecast while I listen to what will be my most anticipated U2 album.  How did this happen, I wonder? <br /> <br />I'm certainly not the standard U2 fan.  My favorite four albums are Pop, Achtung Baby, War, and Boy (in order from most favorite to less).  This album reminds me of All That You Can't Leave Behind, and not so much because of songs or rhythm, but because of an overall rating and sense.  Both albums have annoying long names and seem to lose the listener.  Beautiful Day and Elevation turned into U2's excitement for the album (much like Vertigo and All Because of You may eventually become), but from there on out, nothing stands out.  Sure, New York, Kite, Wild Honey and the rest of sort of grown on me and I now enjoy listening to them, but it took FOUR YEARS!!!  And besides, when I want to listen to U2, I play Discotheque, Sunday Bloody Sunday, Even Better than the Real Thing, With or Without You, Out of Control, Bullet the Blue Sky...  See, though I like the others, I don't dig through a mess of CD's to find `Wild Honey.'  My guess is that many of How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb's songs will turn that way, and I'm left with another mediocre album with only a few hits. <br /> <br />One final remark - Albums such as the Joshua Tree and War are known as U2's great ALBUMS.  Yes, Elevation (especially the Tomb Raider Remix) and Beautiful Day are great U2 SONGS, but whenever someone mentions All That You Can't Leave Behind the crowd will inevitably shrug its shoulders and walk away uninterested. <br /> <br />Well, I it looks like my domain purchases of u2atomic.coom, u2bomb.com and u2atomicbomb.com we're all a bad investment.  Wish me luck next time guys! <br />

B0002TT0NW|4.0|An excellent adventure with loads of directorial style, a welcome change from the static diorama-like feel of the first two movies. The move to Scotland creates a depth of reality to the setting that grounds flights of fancy. I'm no Harry Potter fan, but watching the other films (and reading \\"Order of the Phoenix\\") has convinced me that Rowling's love of creating delightful details, much like JRR Tolkien's love of creating linguistic effects, is best kept in the background for the translation to screen. \\"Prisoner\\" succeeds in this, thankfully reducing the requisite Quidditch sequence that was so tiresome in \\"Stone\\" and \\"Chamber\\", and allowing the fantasy world to exist in and of itself rather than being pointed out and explained at every moment. <br /> <br />The color palette is a briskly refreshing change from the Thomas Kinkade golden glow of the first two movies. Blue and gray gives a gritty, even cruel edge to the environment. <br /> <br />David Thewlis turns in an excellent performance as Lupin, with a quiet and piercing bit of social commentary involving concerned parents not wanting their children to be taught \\"by someone like me\\" and then shutting the various boxes, cases, and closets of his office. Michael Gambon recreates Dumbledore, reducing the ethereal saintliness and adding a faintly perilousness to his humor. Dumbledore must be taken more seriously, it seems. <br /> <br />I was disappointed by the relative lack of screen time given to Gary Oldman, but his best scenes turn the premise of the apparent plot on its ear, and are very touching. <br /> <br />All three of the principals are growing in stature, ability, and, frankly, looks. The varying ways of wearing school uniforms and the presence of real-life clothing makes for a welcome contrast to the fantastic elements, such as the time-turner and the wands. Emma Watson is still a bit stiff, but perhaps that is part of her character. Rupert Grint is ever more appealing, and adding a bit of welcome roughness to Ron. Daniel Radcliffe expresses the ever-more-obvious darker aspects of Harry's power and past with unexpected skill. <br /> <br />The magic itself felt tangible, real, and far from laughable, as it had in the first two movies (with the exception of the revelation of the villain in \\"Chamber\\"). Indeed, the ultimate confrontation between Harry and the dementors was a scene where a very simple visual and sound effect transformed what would be a silly premise into a scene that thrilled, inspired, and awed. <br /> <br />Simply, an excellent movie, and one the non-Potter fan can enjoy (probably more than the devoted Potter fans would.)

B0006399FS|5.0|U2 has released unbelievable music over the past 24 years and their newest album is one of their best.  I understand why some hardcore U2 fans might be disappointed.  U2 is constantly picking up fans as it trucks along through rock history.  For some fans the anger of 'War' represents their U2.  For others its the wild vibes of Achtung and Zooropa.  And now a younger generation has latched onto the soulful pop senisibilties of All That You Can't Leave Behind.  Every single group of fans is protective of and wants to re-live that moment in time when they lost their U2 virginity. <br /> <br />'How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb' is the thesis of U2's long musical journey.  As a result its the most eclectic and even collection of songs they have ever produced.  Yes, such a sonic buffet sacrificies a consistent musical mood or an experimental B-Side to the album.  Most of U2's albums read like a book from start to finish.  But, within those books there were the filler chapters.  The Refugee, 4th of July, & So Cruel are decent songs within the context of their albums, but little else. <br /> <br />After all epic opuses of the 80's and innovation of the 90's U2 just wanted to create and album of the best 10-12 songs possible.  They tried, with some success on ATYCLB, but the 2nd half of that album fell flat on its face. <br /> <br />U2 has stepped up to the challenge this time and has done it.  There is not a bad song on the album.  It wreaks of vintage U2 from many different time periods, but is also totally original.  They also manage to subtely craft the theme of 'the unseen bonds of the world that hold us together'.  And it holds the great songs together.  The uncertainty and fear of Vertigo and Miracle Drug.  The mortality of Sometimes and One Step Closer.  Sexual love in A Man and a Woman.  And don't forget about the master of the unseen, Yahweh.  The band isn't trying too hard to make the tracks this way, but instead it seems to have happened naturally. <br /> <br />Vertigo, Miracle Drug, Sometimes..., City of Blinding Lights, and Original of the Species are some of the greatest songs they have ever produced.  A Man & A Woman, One Step Closer, Crumbs from Your Table, and Yahweh are growers,but will become instant classics to some listeners.  Love & Peace and All Because of You are the only songs that have a hint of being forced, but are still excellent. <br /> <br />Its hard to re-create the magic of Joshua Tree or Achtung Baby, but I believe in time this album will enter that pantheon.  <br /> <br />

Enjoy. <br /> <br />The difference between the limited and the unlimited editions are: The Limited Edition comes in a plastic box with trays, a Neo bust and an 80 page booklet that lists the extras of the 10 disks (yes, that's all it does). Besides this the sets are the same. <br /> <br />These two sets include all three films, The Animatrix, the film footage shot for Enter the Matrix videogame and 106 documentaries. The bonus disks for Reloaded and Revolutions are different from those included in the versions already released. <br /> <br />REMASTERD: The movies were enhanced so the films look brighter in color and richer in details. Don't worry it was not done by Gorge Lucas. The films are the same. <br /> <br />AUDIO: Also enhanced (not that it was necessary). Voices are stronger, gentle noises stand out more and details were sweetened just a bit. Great work! <br /> <br />DISK 1: The Matrix. The original commentaries, the music only audio track, follow the white rabbit, take the red pills... ALL ARE MISSING in this version. It comes with two commentaries worth listening to, a written intro from the Wachowski bros., and a ROM feature. <br /> <br />DISK 2: The Matrix Revisited. It includes the entire contents of the original disk except the fanboy stuff. <br /> <br />DISK 3: The Matrix Reloaded. Two new commentaries and a ROM feature. <br /> <br />DISK 4: The Matrix Reloaded Revisited. All new stuff such as a 17-min look at the fight in the Merovingian's chateau, 55-min dissection of the car chase, 40-min look at the Neo vs. 100 Smith battle, 7-min segment on Neo vs. Seraph and more. <br /> <br />DISK 5: The Matrix Revolutions. Two new commentaries and a ROM feature. <br /> <br />DISK 6: The Matrix Revolutions Revisited. Includes a tour of the set, 27-min piece on the Club Hel fight (ceiling walkers), segments on the workers and extras, 17-min profile of Neo vs. Smith final battle, 36-min piece covering the soundtrack, film editing, etc. and more. <br /> <br />DISK 7: The Animatrix. Just as we all remember it. <br /> <br />DISK 8: The Roots of the Matrix. Two documentaries: 1-Return to Source: The Philosophy of The Matrix: is an hour long discussion on the philosophical elements of the movie. And 2-The Hard Problem: the Science Behind the Fiction is an hour long discussion of the science of the films and its possibilities for a real life Matrix. <br /> <br />DISK 9: The Burly Man Chronicles. This is a 94-min featurette documenting the whole 276 day shoot for films 2 and 3. Profiles, interviews, a tribute to Alliyah and more are also found on this disk. Although almost nothing is said about Gloria Foster (the original Oracle). <br /> <br />DISK 10: The Zion Archive. Here we find storyboards and concept art for all three films; trailers and music videos for all three films; video effects in various states of completion and a Matrix Online game preview. <br /> <br />Overall: Excellent collection and a must for fans. If you are not a hardcore fan though and you like this collection, you may want to purchase the one without Neo's bust. It's cheaper and the booklet is only a guide to the extras on the 10 disks which are all included in both sets. The Wachowskis DO NOT give any commentaries on these disks which may be disappointing for some fans. But over all this is a great collection. You may add it to the ones you already own with confidence. There are more goodies in these disks not mentioned here so have fun exploring. Just follow the white rabbit and remember... there is no spoon. <br />

B00014K5TQ|5.0|I LOVED this film.  I knew of Alig and had seen \\"Party Monster-The Shockumentary\\" and wanted more.  Well, \\"Party Monster\\" delivered. <br /> <br />Mackauly Culkin and Seth Green have both received scathing reviews of their portrayal of the wacky Club Kids Michael Alig and James St. James.  They have been called plastic, over the top, and just plain too queer.  Well, what better describes these two real-life larger than life characters?  The actors' affected, stiff portrayals are a brilliant interpretation of the constant theatre put on by such infamous Club Kids.  I used to be annoyed by Culkin, but after this, and \\"Saved\\" he has joined his brother Kieran at the top of my list of great actors.  I can even forgive Seth Green his MTV affiliation after this performance. <br /> <br />To continue, the casting was sublime and Marilyn Manson was a stroke of genius to fill the sparkling platform shoes of Christina.  The costuming was dead-on and avoided looking too \\"Hollywood\\" by maintaining that home-made quality to the outfits that were originally fashioned by broke kids.  The soundtrack was appropriate but never obvious, a trap many 1980's period films fall into.  The script was funny, objective, shocking and even touching at times.  The cinematography was well done and I especially enjoyed the film angles in the hotel room bathroom and out of the rat's hole.   <br /> <br />In short, I loved it. <br />Favorite line:  \\"That's not a crack hole, it's a rat hole.  Rats on crack attack!\\" <br />

B000002H6C|5.0|\\"I pledge allegiance to Metallica!\\" This is what came to my mind after listening to Metallica's 1988 hit album \\"And Justice for All...\\" The album captures exactly what true heavy metal actually is and stands for. From the first inspirational harmonized guitar intro to \\"Blackened\\" (the first song on the album), to the fast double bass, down and dirty ending to Dyers Eve, the album sends you on a emotional rollercoaster ride through their life perspectives which has been a catharsis for all those who listen.    Blackened, the opening song for the album, does such a great job introducing the greatest metal band of all time, that Metallica uses it as the opening song at almost every one of their shows. The songs on this album all have strong relevant lyrics, that effect anyone who listens. Also musically the lyrics emotions are complemented and encouraged by the instrumentals throughout every single song. There is not one song that lacks emotion, creativity or talent on the whole album.   \\"I can't remember anything, Can't tell if this is true or dream, Deep down inside I feel to scream, This terrible silence stops me.\\" This is the first verse of \\"One\\" which is quite possibly one of Metallica's most intelligent and exciting creations. It starts off with a solemn feel accompanied by a lone acoustic guitar in the background which gradually rises up to an explosion of frustrated emotions in a war on one's life.   In the song \\"Dyers Eve\\" James's lyrics are expressing the acute frustration he had when living with his family as they censored what he did, what he said, and where he was. He looks at his family as a creative barrier during his childhood and expresses his absolute disgust with that. \\"Dear Mother, Dear Father, You've clipped my wings before, I learned to fly, Unspoiled, Unspoken, I've outgrown that f******* lullaby, Same thing I've always heard from you, `Do as I say, not as I do'\\" this verse shows how James could persevere through even during the worst times that they were trying to hold him back.    Metallica is so often overlooked by many people as just another metal band that sings about killing, raping, and other sadistic things, but in reality their lyrics show the true emotions behind the band members and the views they have on the world. Metallica is an example to the entire metal scene, and they are the ultimate metal force in the world. The \\"And Justice for All...\\" album in every aspect is their greatest creation to date as far as I am concerned. And even if you are just looking for a hard hitting in your face album with tons of face melting guitar solos than you would be right at home with this album.

B00005JLD4|5.0|In a time where movie producers are continuously trying to one-up each other with bigger-and-badder CGI spectacles, watching a film like this is refreshing. Completely stripped of pretension, prettiness, and unneccasary dribble, it is a story that speaks directly to the heart. Director Phillip Noyce (The Quiet American) and D.P. Christopher Doyle give us a vast and seemingly endless Australian desert landscape. In tune with the wonderfully placid score by Peter Gabriel, the results are hypnotic and compelling. There are stretches where very few lines of dialogue are spoken. The camera simply places these three young girls in the harshest reaches of the desert terrain, and we understand, if only slightly, what the real experience must have been like.  <br /> <br />The film tells a simple story of what it means to feel secure as a child and be with family. It also explores the effects of an age old racial stereotype that was then policy of the Australian government; Blacks must integrate and adjust to white society. And worse, Blacks are not able to raise their own children. It works because it does not trap itself inside a fixed and conventional narrative. Noyce explores his themes well, without throwing them in our faces as so many films regrettably do. We as the viewers are immersed into the journey across 1,500 miles of unforgiving desert, as the young girls try to outmaneuver the men sent to recapture them. <br /> <br />This is a beautiful film in its ability to captivate and move us in unexpected ways. The last few shots show us the two surviving sisters, now old and weak, and we hear Molly in voice-over tell us how their family is still being ruined by racial prejudice. We sympathize with them, of course. But we notice they are smiling, unwavering in their optimism and love of life. They lost a sister on their journey back home, and Molly lost her daughter for good. But something deep down in the heart tells them to keep going.  <br /> <br />

1592400876|5.0|I just finished reading Lynne Truss's fantastic book, Eats, Shoots, and Leaves. While many of my writer friends have said they won't read it because \\"I don't need any more grammer and punctuation lessons, thank you very much,\\" it is NOT just a book on proper punctuation or grammar. It IS a humorous look at how the English language has evolved over the centuries, and the origins of some of our modern day punctuation. You may be surprised by the things you learn, as well as being thoroughly entertained by Ms. Truss's wonderfully acerbic wit. There's nothing like Brit-humour to get me snorting through my nose with laughter on the bus!

0671015206|5.0|Unless you were born into family wealth and privilege, you have two options: 1. You can look like a millionaire.  2. You can one day BE a millionaire.  I know which one I choose. <br /> <br />It will perhaps be a revelation to many people to discover that the folks who drive the fanciest cars, live in the most chi-chi neighborhoods in the ritziest homes, and who refuse to shop anywhere but Neiman-Marcus are usually cash-poor.  They may even have negative net worth, due to their huge pile of consumer debt.  But the family down the block from you?  You know...the ones in the 3-bedroom, 1900-sq. ft. house, driving the 8 year old Corolla?  The ones you wait in line with at Target?  They're millionaires. <br /> <br />I find it interesting that the negative reviewers of this very useful and practical guide all seem to say the same thing: \\"You can't possibly enjoy your life if you save some of the money you earn instead of spending it all!\\"  Unwittingly, they serve as the perfect illustration of the UAWs (Under-Accumulators of Wealth) mentioned in the book.  UAWs may earn very high salaries, but they are also so obsessed with collecting status symbols (huge McMansions, swimming pools, country club memberships, new $50,000 cars every two years, etc.) that they are constantly strapped for cash.  Case in point: \\"Dr. North\\" (or was it Dr. South?), a physician mentioned in the book.  Dr. N. has an incredibly successful practice and, in his late 50s, makes $700,000 per year.  His net worth?  Barely half of his yearly salary!  And most of that is in home equity. <br /> <br />PAWs (Prodigious Accumulators of Wealth), on the other hand, follow a few simple rules: they \\"pay themselves first\\" (ie: save a set amount of money every month rather than waiting to have enough left over to begin saving someday in the future); they don't purchase something until they can afford it, rather than assuming that \\"one day I'll have the money, so I may as well buy this on credit now\\"; and perhaps most importantly, they don't allow themselves to get caught up into the escalating madness of keeping up with the Joneses.  True wealth doesn't lie in having whatever you want; it's wanting whatever you have.   <br /> <br />Unless you were born with a silver spoon in your mouth, you probably can't afford to live the way you assume millionaires live and still actually become a millionaire yourself.  Think about it - if a guy making $700K per year isn't a millionaire because of his spending habits, what chance do the rest of us have?  On the other hand, if you make a good salary (say $45K and up), are prudent, and follow some of the basic guidelines for building wealth, you have an excellent shot at one day actually BEING a millionaire - even if you don't look like one. <br />
B000002KB8|5.0|I want to say up front that I don't specifically recommend that you purchase this album: If you're metal fan I'd dare say that you are virutally obligated to own their Black Box set, which naturally contains this album.  However, for my own personal amusement I will write a review for this album in particular.<br /><br />This album marks the birth of Metal, no doubt about it.  However, I can't quite say that it's a metal album, as there's a bit too much blues jamming and whatnot. Still, the title track and N.I.B. are pure, unadulterated metal.  And, I rather enjoy the jamming and other non and pre-metal aspects of the album, and think it is definitely a bit underrated in the Black Sabbath canon.(I don't think it's as good as Paranoid, MoR or Sabotage, but I think it comes closer than most people seem to feel)<br /><br />You've got to have heard a good portion of this album, but I'll go over it all anyway.  The title track, is an utter classic, and as good as your slow, ominous metal song can get. Ozzy's barely controlled vox are used to perfect effect, and the lyrics aren't quite silly enough to weaken the whole song(The faster riffing at the end is pretty sweet too.)  The Wizard is underrated, perhaps the best song on the album.  Iommi's stuttering, start and stop rhythm guitar work is simply awesome, and the loose, snare-riding drumming underneath it compliments it perfectly.  Behind the Wall of Sleep and Bassically are a fine introduction to the next all-time classic, the legendary N.I.B.  The main riff is utterly classic, but it's the smoother, more melodic guitar lines that are thrown in later that really hold the song together, and the sharp, slick lead work.  Ozzy's vox again fit in perfectly, once again.(Ozzy has a very limited range.  It's amazing that they used it so effectively on this album) Second best track on the album.  Wicked World is pretty strong too, with more blues in it and a fairly jazzy feel at times.  It's definitely good, but not in the league of the first 3 tracks..  Track 5, which I'll simply refer to as Warning, for simplicity's sake, is another classic.  The jamming is quite entertaining, but I absolutely love the main parts of the song.  The chorus is very memorable, one of the best they'd ever written.  And the introduction is very nice and moody as well.  Evil Woman is the only weakpoint in the album.  It's just kinda blah.  Still, it's not terrible, and the rest of the album is strong enough to make up for it, easily.<br /><br />Yes, this rules.  Get the Black Box now!league of the first 3 tracks..  Track 5, which I'll simply refer to as Warning, for simplicity's sake, is another classic.  The jamming is quite entertaining, but I absolutely love the main parts of the song. Still, it's not terrible, and the rest of the album is strong enough to make up for it, easily.  <br /> <br />Yes, this rules.  Get the Black Box now!

The song hows that Dio's songwriting involves a lot of fantasy, unlike the dark songs that the earlier band was known for. A little short compared to many other Sabbath songs, but still satisfying. Children of the Sea: I have to say, this song isn't nearly the best, but still great. the speed, although Geezer's guitar is heavy, nothing is done to bump up the pace. 3/5 and a half. Lady Evil: Pretty good song. superb rhythm by Geezer and Iommi in the intro, medium speed throughout the song. 4/5. Heaven and Hell: Very strong song, great vocals by Dio. Pretty slow at first, but the pace accelerates towards the end, great lyrics. 5/5! Wishing Well: Would probably get a 4/5, except the lyrics and the song are a tad boring. Great solo by Iommi that just seems to swirl around in your head. 3/5 and a half. Die Young: Easily the best song on the album. sounds remniscent of the end of Heaven and Hell though. Walk Away: Not too good. what else can I say? 2/5 and a half. Lonely is the Word: Heavy guitar, but way to slow. one of those strange \\"romance\\" songs like Walk Away, not what fans are used to, some repetitive guitar. 3/4. Overview: Great album despite the shortcomings.
B0002OERI0|5.0|Growing up in San Diego I saw Green Day a number of times in concert before Dookie came out and owned their earlier albums as well.  They were a special band at that time in California because few Punk acts around could match their live performances or the quality of their songwriting.  Dookie's success completely blind sided me when it came out but it was well deserved. They prove the old saying that it doesn't matter what genre a band comes from, all that matters is writing good songs that connect with the listener.  Green Day always achieved these goals and they built a huge regional following because of it.<br /><br />They pretty much stayed in one place musically with Insomniac and Nimrod though Warning was a real step forward in the growth department.  With American Idiot Green Day have released their true masterpiece and I am stunned that they did it so late in the game.  In an era where most bands get dropped by their fans after two albums its hard for most acts to stick around long enough to reach this type of zenith and few even if given the chance to do so can use this added time wisely.<br /><br />I was like a previous reviewer who bought it along with some other releases and ended up listening to it non stop from that point on.  The single American Idiot does not reflect the overall brilliance that the rest of this album contains.  As a concept album it works suprisingly well though you can listen to it without feeling that some of the songs serve only as filler.  Nothing is wasted on this release.  Some have commented that concept albums have been done before and Punk is hardly new but lets face it, Rock as a whole is roughly 50 years old now and there are only so many things you can do with a guitar, bass and drums.  What matters, again, is whether an artist can write good songs and few are writing them better than Billie Joe Armstrong is on this release.<br /><br />It's ultimately an album that combines the best of what they offered on their previous releases but stands on its own as a master stroke of genius that only the most cynical could deny.  I don't know how they did it but they did and we are all richly rewarded because of it.<br /><br />Stand Out Tracks:<br /><br />American Idiot<br /><br />Holiday<br /><br />Boulevard of Broken Dreams<br /><br />Give Me Novacaine<br /><br />Extraordinary Girl<br /><br />Letterbombprevious releases but stands on its own as a master stroke of genius that only the most cynical could deny. B0006399FS|4.0|Reading all of these reviews is disheartening because many people are starting to criticize this great band for making commercials and promoting themselves when there is nothing wrong with that.  Bono is egomanical, his lyrics are far from subtle, and we love that about him. The Edge's guitar parts are familiar but always fresh enough to keep you wanting more, and the band is far from finished by the sound of this CD.  Its more of an extension from All That You Can't Leave Behind, rather than a rehash.  Its stronger and more confident than ATYCB, and the band seems to be having more fun rather than worrying about recapturing something that they lost with Zooropa and Pop.  They know what they do best and damn do they do it well.  The songs are definitely catchy (especially Vertigo, All Because of You, Sometimes You Can't Make it on Your Own) and for anyone to say otherwise is to be listening with a skeptics ear towards a band that has managed to remain as the most popular in the world for 25 years!  If they have to make a commercial or two or sell an Ipod to make sure that people are still listening, then that's fine with me as long as the music is still this good.  Buy the CD, you won't be disappointed and you may even be surprised at how good it really is.

1577312082|5.0|By all means, read the comments of the critics. Interestingly enough, they make the argument FOR the Power of Now much better than I can. The critics operate from a conceptual premise to analyze the idea of being present. Tolle believes that Presence is devoid of thought. You cannot understand Presence in a theoretical sense; to be Present you must be Present. <br /> <br />  NOte: When I refer to 'Critics' I'm categorizing all of us who have at some time, had or used predispositions and prejudices (pre-judgments) with regard to anything in our lives: people, places, things and ideas.  <br /> <br />  The mind based arguments are inherently flawed because they are logically founded and thereby naturally inclined to fight against being present. Simply, when you are Present there is no argument.   This is the beauty of Tolle's book. Tolle is not a philospher (because then his teachings would be merely theoretical) but he points you in the direction to be free of the useless, often debilitating, chatter of the mind.  <br />Tolle seems to believe that with just the optimal use of your senses you are Present. What else is there. Certainly, not the past or future.  <br /> <br />   The Critics Weaknesses. <br />1) The critics need to make Tolle wrong. That is nothing more than the egoic, self righteous mind which is threatened. The egoic mind rallies to stave off any attempt to be free of self importance. <br />2) The critics are caught up in the importance of their argument  and words. Tolle uses words merely as signposts; the words in and of themselves are unimportant. They are only tools used for direction.  <br />3) Apple Pie Analogy. Essentially, the critics, being mind based, experience an apple pie with predispositions and prejudices (pre-judgments) about how the pie should taste. They will spoil the experience by arguing what you need more of, less of, taste, color and size. They will not experience the apple pie as it IS. Hence, the mind contaminates the Present moment. Tolle suggests that the \\"Present\\" person will have an inner body experience with all sensory perceptions: taste, smells, textures, chewing, swallowing, etc.   <br /> <br />While we, as critics, may be on a mission to 'search' for the \\"Truth\\", unfortunately, our analytical mind seeks to destroy the 'essence' of our being. And you need only ask yourself if you are at Peace. If not, then why would heed the advice of a critic who obviously is caught up in mental warefare and is also not at peace. The book in excellent, and if nothing else, it is provocative and non-threatening. Enjoy! Pete.

B00000IQW3|4.0|THE LAST STARFIGHTER is definitely a product of the 1980s. The hair, some of the clothes, the video arcades, the cars, etc. Despite the time period in which it is set, it does a wonderful job of tying in to everything that's great about youth and the optimism of coming of age.<br /><br />The movie tells the story of Alex Rogan (Lance Guest). Alex is a young kid living in a trailer park who dreams of bigger things and unlike many of those at home, is trying to pursue those dreams. He wants to go to college away from home and begin a new life. Only thing is, he gets rejected from the school he applies to. So Alex starts playing the arade. The trailer park has one arcade game outside of its little country store and Alex is a pro at it. The game is called Starfighter and one night Alex ends up beating the game and achieving an all time new high score.  The next day a man named Centauri who claims to be a representative of the company who invented the game shows up to meet with Alex. Turns out, Centauri is an alien who invented the game to find new recruits to join the Star League, an elite group of starfighters who keep the peace throughout the galaxy. Centauri takes Alex to Star League command and he is given a whirlwind tour. The situation is overwhelming for the lad and he requests to be sent home. He does, but by then things have gotten way out of hand and before Alex can say Beta, he finds out that he's the last starfighter.<br /><br />The acting in the movie is good, especially for a cheesy 1980s sci-fi, boy in space picture.  Robert Preston made his final motion picture performance in THE LAST STARFIGHTER and watching some of the behind the scenes stuff on the DVD it's clear that the man was much more talented than many people ever gave him credit for.  The special effects in THE LAST STARFIGHTER might seem lame by todays standards but they really aren't all that bad. TRON is recognized as being the first movie to use CGI, but it was THE LAST STARFIGHTER that first used CGI for all its special effects. The effects were produed by the now-ancient Cray Super Computer.<br /><br />The movie actually is a joy to watch. It's got some snappy dialogue, some interesting concepts (the whole Beta thing), and the first feature length CGI effects in a major motion picture. The film isn't going to change anyone's life, but it is a great movie to sit back and watch at home with a cool Dr Pepper and a bucket full of buttered popcorn. A delightful piece of mind candy that speaks to child in all of us.<br /><br />The DVD special features include the director commentary, a behind the scenes featurette, production photos and info, and theatrical trailers.all its special effects. B0006399FS|5.0|Over the past 20+ years we've heard U2 play all kinds of music (well, except hip-hop), and one interesting anti-trend that they set, if you will, is that they are musical iconoclasts.  Take their gritty and political breakthrough album War, which contrasts with the 80's mainstream rock trend of hairbands and synthesizers.  Then comes the age of grunge, and they turn around to make Achtung Baby.  Now, in the days of popular \\"hard\\" rock sounds that consists of pretentious edginess and high-decibel noise, here comes U2 with another Atomic Bomb. <br /> <br />I've heard many people complain that the CD in its entirety is not represented by their first single and the opening track, Vertigo.  My feeling is, so what?  The songs are seamlessly bound together lyrically and thematically, and many of the tracks past Vertigo are on par or even better.  \\"Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own\\" is the best song in the album, with amazing writing and heartbreaking vocal performance, especially when understood in the context of the death of Bono's father Bob Hewson a few years ago. <br /> <br />Overall it's a great album.  I'm not putting it up there with Achtung Baby and Joshua Tree right away, but it's getting better and better every time I listen to it.

Me and my friends alike have become MEGA MEGA Evanescence fans. <br />The music is classically driven with Strings, piano and a blend of metal that other bands just can't match. Kudos to Evanescence for bringing there music to the world. This Album is one of a kind! Every song on this CD is remarkable. Im looking forward to more Cd's from them
B0006399FS|5.0|This album is without a doubt U2's best work since 1991's Achtung Baby. However, I would liken it more to their even earlier masterpiece-1987's The Joshua Tree- in that it is a consistent album of solid songs but also contains some singularly powerful singles. Their last album, 2000's All That You Can't Leave Behind, was an exciting change of direction for the band (who were still rebounding from the disappointment of 1997's Pop) with some truly memorable moments (Beautiful Day, Walk On, In a Little While...) but was ultimately disappointing in it's ability to play repeatedly over the years as so many U2 greats have. This new album, however, has that strange and truly gratifying feeling of being both completely fresh and new and feeling like it's always been there in the back of your head. Maybe that's because it so seamlessly combines old and new styles. The Edge is back in his glorious bombastic form, and it sounds like he's been anxiously awaiting the return as he is definetely the star of this show. His signature guitar chime from the 80's hasn't been employed this much since...the 80's, and it sounds better than ever! Songs like \\"City of Blinding Lights\\" and \\"Crumbs From Your Table\\" scream classic U2. In fact, \\"City..' has a structure similar to the perrenial classic \\"Where the Streets Have no Name,\\" right down to the minute-and-a-half guitar intro. The highlights of this great disc include \\"City...\\", \\"A Man and a Woman,\\" (which has a particularly profound meaning in my life at the moment), \\"Crumbs...,\\"\\"Sometimes You Can't Make it On Your Own,\\"\\"Miracle Drug,\\" and \\"Love and Peace or Else!\\" That being said, the whole album is good and listenable all the way through. My initial reaction to the album as a long-time fan anxiously awaiting it (as I have with all their past efforts) was sheer joy to the fact that I never truly thought I would here songs of this quality and energy from this group again, although it's not a complete return to form in terms of styling, just energy and substance. And while their best work is still probably behind them (It's hard to top The Joshua Tree after all and nearly impossible to top Achtung Baby), it's very refreshing and reassuring to have music this strong from a band this consistently relevant. U2 have always been reliable, but this Bomb is surprisingly potent!

She just sits and smiles at the animal sounds. It really grabs her attention. She's able to focus on the pictures and sounds, so it's a great introduction to books and reading. This is a great beginning book for parents to read to their babies.

B0006399FS|5.0|Like a lot of U2 fans (and rock fans in general), I've been waiting a long time for this album ... more than 2 1/2 years. Was it worth the wait? I've spun the CD five times now and can say yes, yes, and yes -- it's the best album U2 have yet produced. <br /> <br />I'll paraphrase another reviewer who called HTDAAB the offspring of Achtung Baby and The Joshua Tree; it is all that and more, but it surpasses even those classic albums with its astonishing heart and musical passion. Bono's lyrics and singing aside, this disc contains some GREAT music. The Edge's guitar is like a combination chainsaw/machine-gun, and Larry and Adam of course provide mesmerizing rhythm. <br /> <br />\\"Atomic Bomb\\" is miles ahead of \\"All That You Can't Leave Behind,\\" that much should go without saying. There isn't a single bit of dead weight anywhere on the record, though it's definitely an ALBUM. You should sit down, free yourself of distractions, maybe light a candle and pop open a cold beer, and just ENJOY, at top volume. This is an album to grow old with. <br /> <br />A song-by-song run-through: <br />Vertigo: A solid rocker and a great arena anthem, though it's easily the least song on the album. Best line: \\"The girl with crimson nails/has Jesus round her neck/swinging to the music.\\" <br />Miracle Drug: Took me a couple of turns to switch onto this track, but it's a great U2 song, full of heart and emotion, with a strong solo from The Edge. Best line: \\"Of science and the human heart/there is no limit.\\" <br />Sometimes You Can't Make It ... OK, I dare you to get through this song without weeping. A classic ballad, instantly up there with \\"One\\" and \\"Running To Stand Still,\\" but maybe a little better, as it is so nakedly personal. Bono has never sounded better. Best line: \\"And it's you when I look in the mirror/and it's you when I don't pick up the phone ...\\" <br />Love and Peace or Else: Wow, this track sounds just like U2 without sounding anything at all like U2. Might take a couple of spins to grow on you, but it amps up and rocks the walls down. A fantastic rocker that would make Black Rebel Motorcycle Club a tad envious. Best line: \\"Lay down your guns/all your daughters of Zion/All your Abraham sons.\\" This will be fantastic live. <br />City of Blinding Lights: An epic rocker, lit up like a city at night. Will easily stand alongside \\"New Years Day\\" a few years from now. Built for arenas. Best line: \\"They're advertising in the skies/for people like us.\\" <br />All Because of You: One of the best! A heavy, garage-band sound permeates this hard-rocking track that's destined for heavy radio rotation (and deserves it). Ranks up there with \\"Mysterious Ways\\" with its funky guitar riff. Best line: \\"Some people got high rises on their backs.\\" <br />A Man And a Woman: Should solidify Bono as one of the finest soul singers in the world. Another strong radio contender, with a groovy bassline from Mr. Clayton. I love this song. Best line: \\"I been sleeping in the street again/like a stray dog.\\" <br />Crumbs From Your Table: The band deflates mainstream religion on this beautiful track that happens to rock as hard as \\"Vertigo.\\" EXCELLENT guitarwork from The Edge, highly reminiscent of \\"The Joshua Tree.\\" And great vocals from Bono, of course. Best line: \\"With a mouthful of teeth/you ate all your friends.\\" <br />One Step Closer: A slower number, full of empty spaces, but beautifully poetic, full of gorgeous nighttime images of Bono caught somewhere between life and death. Every line in the song is a killer. <br />Original of the Species: Probably the most difficult track on the album; don't give it one fast listen and then dismiss it. Come back later, two or three times, let it grow on you. You'll understand that this song puts U2 firmly in Beatles territory. Best line: \\"Some people got way too much confidence, baby.\\" <br />Yahweh: Here U2 come dangerously close to self-parody with a song that addresses God directly and by name. But they pull it off the right way,by making the song and the chorus so big, so heartfelt, and so genuinely poetic that, by Yahweh, you'll have tears in your eyes while you're singing along. Best line: \\"This love is like a drop in the ocean.\\" <br /> <br />What else can I say? It's the ultimate U2 album, the one they've been working toward for 26 years. Yeah, we had to wait a long time, but the end result is fantastic. Those expecting something different or \\"better\\" would probably have never been satisfied with anything. The refreshing thing about U2 is that they continue to move forward without losing sight of the things that fire them up. These guys are going to go down in history as one of the top five bands ever, if they're not already there.
B0006399FS|5.0|Vertigo-Straight on rock...everyone has heard this one by now! <br />Miracle Drug-Beautifal song that just keeps building <br />Sometime You Can't Make it On Your Own-Brilliant song that Bono wrote for his father on his death bed. <br />Love and Peace or Else-For those of us who like the riskier U2 this is the real stand out on the album....heavy! <br />City of Blinding Lights-Great song that will be a great sing along at the concerts. <br />All Because of You-Another one that you just turn up your stereo and enjoy. <br />A man and A Woman-This has the feel of an All That You Can't Leave Behind leftover but it is very infectuous after several listens and has turned into a favorite. <br />Crumbs From Your Table-Great lyrics and a great song....very solid....rumor has it U2 wrote this one while they were trashed. <br />One Step Closer-This is a great lead in to the final 2 songs....has a very Unforgettable Fire feel to it. <br />Original of The Species-This may be one of the top 10 songs U2 has ever done. B00068IOWC|5.0|...this one ranks up there with the very best of U2.  I have loved the band since *Boy*, and my fave albums were the late 80s albums (*Unforgettable Fire*, *Joshua Tree*, and *Rattle and Hum*).   <br /> <br />While there is much to love in the 1990s catalog, and *All You Can't Leave Behind* was also a well-done album (backed by the best tour EVER), this album pulls together all the sounds that have helped define U2 and its transitions over the years.  This is the cleanest, best package I've heard since *Joshua Tree*.  Bono found his best poetry again (maybe the return this year of that case of lyrics lost so long ago was providential), the Edge is TIGHT, and, as always, Adam and Larry provide the bass/percussion foundation that has made this band so consistently good for 25 years.  And they have finally made an art of drawing on other musical influences while still sounding like U2, not imitative.  (If you listen closely, you'll hear touches of everything from the Beatles to P.J. Harvey.)  They came close with *New York* on the last album, but they've done an even better job here. <br /> <br />This is a fine work to usher one of the legendary Rock and Roll Bands into the Hall of Fame next year.  And the best part is they are still making some of their best music - something that doesn't always apply to Hall of Famers.

B0006399FS|5.0|Who hadn't heard Vertigo before Atomic Bomb album came out?  U2, in brilliant marketing, decided to be very active before this album came out, putting Vertigo all over the baseball playoffs, introducing a great U2 iPod, and featuring articles in newspapers and magazines.  And they are allowed to, thanks to the album they have put out.  <br /> <br />Much like \\"Pride\\" was the hit single off The Unforgettable Fire yet felt out of place with the sound of that album, so too does Vertigo belie the rest of Atomic Bomb.  There are no songs that rock like Vertigo does, not even Love and Peace or Else, which sounds like a mix between Achtung and \\"Bullet the Blue Sky.\\"  No, the rest of the album is indeed a little slower, but not quieter.  ATYCLB was a tremendous album for me, but if anything was wrong with it, it was fairly weak musically for these guys, with the exception of Beautiful Day.  But on Atomic Bomb, even if you think the songs are too soft, they're active, and the instruments sound great.   <br /> <br />As has been said, this is indeed an Edge album.  He takes over many of the songs.  His sound is at once something I've never heard from him yet hearkens back to Unforgettable Fire and Joshua Tree time.   <br /> <br />His best songs are Bono's best as well.  Vertigo (which does have significant lyrics, if you listen for meaning behind the great music), Miracle Drug, and City of Blinding Lights are the songs that will be classics.  Original of the Species and One Step Closer to Knowing are both very good, and we knew all about Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own before it came out, and the lyrics are truly open, vulnerable, more emotional than anything else on the album, which is a personal one.  The best part of this song is the bridge, by far. <br /> <br />The guitar coming from Edge on Miracle Drug and City of Blinding Lights, in particular, is tremendous, epic, anthemic, intimate, emotional, just like the lyrics.  More than anything, the words to this album fit the music. <br /> <br />And Bono's lyrics are great, as always.  \\"Would you deny for others what you demand for yourself?\\" ...On Vertigo, he portrays himself trying to find good in a world of terror and anguish.  In Miracle Drug, a person (from someone he knew) trying to get the thoughts out of his head despite a brain disorder - \\"There is no failure here, sweetheart / Just when you quit.\\" ...In City of Blinding Lights, is it a loss of innocence?  A love song to New York?  A great landscape song?  Bono is famous for his ambiguous lyrics, which is perhaps why so many people relate to them.   <br /> <br />But we have had only a day to listen to this album.  U2's albums often require time to fully appreciate them--Unforgettable, Achtung, and ATYCLB are examples.  (Boy, War and Joshua are great from the start.)  In a way, all we're listening for now is the sound, the instruments, and they sound great.  After a few listenings one can begin to dissect the lyrics, but the sound is what hits you first.  But U2 has accomplished what has always been a trademark - each album has a similar sound throughout, yet one that is different from each other album's.   <br /> <br />U2 are one of rock's last remaining greats, and they've eclipsed most of the ones before them.  Instead of talking about sex and drugs, they manage to put emotion, hope, faith, death, mortality, and feeling into rock.  For this we should be grateful.
B00024BHTC|5.0|I don't usually write reviews, but I was tired of seeing reviews by individuals with closed minds.
